"Legal marriage" in the sense we think of it today is a relatively recent thing. Religious marriage (or cultural marriage) has been around a lot longer. Cultural marriage, I believe, exists because there is something in our human nature that knows monogamy between a man and a woman is a good thing. 
 
 When we talk about legal marriage in the modern sense, what we're really talking about is couples' benefits. The govt. uses marriage as a criteria to give benefits. When it's all said and done, that's all legal marriage really is.

 I believe marriage is a civil issue. For legislative purposes, that positions it as a states right be it man/woman, man/man, female/female or frog/frog. If discrimination is involved with cultural morality demanding belief system standards while disregarding equality, as currently present in many states, then the constitution and SCOTUS interpretation will eventually become involved. With current administration's 'back to the '50s focus', the gays I know as personal friends feel somewhat akin to African Americans circa 1950s. If and when SCOTUS does have to consider the issue, I can only hope that select group of individuals is capable of separating belief system morality from the reality of constitutional rights of equality.

 Equality really isn't a constitutional issue. When this comes before the SCOTUS, and it will, I think it'll be on state's rights grounds. The states have the right to decide who they want to give marriage licenses to. The states do not, however, have the right to say that a marriage that's legal in one state isn't legal in their state. I believe that what the SCOTUS will affirm is that states can decide not to marry gays, but must recognize gay marriages legally performed in other states.
